title: My dad's life was cut short by polio – I know the horrors of this terrible disease
text:
Like thousands of others in the UK, my childhood was shaped by polio’s legacy. While he was serving in the navy during the war, my dad, Michael Flanders, caught polio.

It put him in a wheelchair from the age of 21, and was a large part of the reason he didn’t live to see me grow up.

In many ways, my story is not that unusual. It took nearly three decades from the rollout of the first polio vaccine in the 1950s for the disease to be eradicated in the UK.

For a younger generation, polio may seem like a problem that has already been consigned to the history books. But for many of us, it isn’t. Today, there are an estimated 100,000 British survivors of the disease.

For those of us who’ve seen what this disease can do first-hand, the UK’s global role in the fight against polio is a source of enormous pride.
